articles.headline: Candidates Clash Over Character and Policy
articles.snippet: Senator John McCain raised questions about Senator Barack Obama in their most combative encounter.
articles.abstract: Senator John McCain raised questions about Senator Barack Obama in their most combative encounter.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator John McCain used the final debate of the presidential election on Wednesday night to raise persistent and pointed questions about Senator Barack Obama’s character, judgment and policy prescriptions in a session that was by far the most spirited and combative of their encounters this fall.

articles.headline: Cuomo Seeks Recovery of Bonuses at A.I.G.
articles.snippet: New York’s attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, demanded that the insurer recover bonuses and other payments from its former executives, lest he take formal action against the company.
articles.abstract: New York’s attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, demanded that the insurer recover bonuses and other payments from its former executives, lest he take formal action against the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: New York’s attorney general demanded on Wednesday that the American International Group recover bonuses and other payments from its former executives, lest he take formal action against the insurer.
articles.byline: By Jonathan D. Glater and Vikas Bajaj

articles.headline: Mob Muscles Its Way Into Politics in Bulgaria
articles.snippet: Far from halting crime and violence, European Union aid to Bulgaria has effectively helped to spread corruption.
articles.abstract: Far from halting crime and violence, European Union aid to Bulgaria has effectively helped to spread corruption.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOFIA, Bulgaria — Politics is played to the death in Bulgaria, where the lives of politicians can be as cheap as spent bullets and murky business groups wage a murderous struggle for their cut of everything from real estate deals to millions in European aid.
articles.byline: By Doreen Carvajal and Stephen Castle

articles.headline: Home Prices Seem Far From Bottom
articles.snippet: Home prices are likely to fall through late 2009, if not longer, economists say.
articles.abstract: Home prices are likely to fall through late 2009, if not longer, economists say.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American housing market, where the global economic crisis began, is far from hitting bottom.

articles.headline: A Somali Influx Unsettles Latino Meatpackers
articles.snippet: In Nebraska, tension is emerging as Somali immigrants fill jobs once held by Latino workers taken away in raids.
articles.abstract: In Nebraska, tension is emerging as Somali immigrants fill jobs once held by Latino workers taken away in raids.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRAND ISLAND, Neb.  Like many workers at the meatpacking plant here, Raul A. Garcia, a Mexican-American, has watched with some discomfort as hundreds of Somali immigrants have moved to town in the past couple of years, many of them to fill jobs once held by Latino workers taken away in immigration raids.

articles.headline: Lending Alternative Hits Hurdle
articles.snippet: One the most audacious ideas of the Web 2.0 boom — that people could lend money to other people over the Internet and cut out banks, is experiencing a squeeze.
articles.abstract: One the most audacious ideas of the Web 2.0 boom — that people could lend money to other people over the Internet and cut out banks, is experiencing a squeeze.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  It was one of the most audacious ideas of the Web 2.0 boom  that people could lend money to other people over the Internet and cut out the middlemen, also known as traditional banks.

articles.headline: Asia Looks to Its Own Consumers to Bolster the Region’s Economies
articles.snippet: As spending falls in the U.S. and Europe, Asian consumers may be the last hope to preserve economic growth around the world — if Asians can be encouraged to spend.
articles.abstract: As spending falls in the U.S. and Europe, Asian consumers may be the last hope to preserve economic growth around the world — if Asians can be encouraged to spend.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUANGZHOU, China  For years, Asians have been held up as an example to the world for their discipline in saving rather than spending. Now their leaders are trying to break them of that habit.

articles.headline: A Look at Google’s First Phone
articles.snippet: A rival to the iPhone is about to debut, with software by Google, body by HTC and network by T-Mobile.
articles.abstract: A rival to the iPhone is about to debut, with software by Google, body by HTC and network by T-Mobile.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Google phone is real, and it’s finally here. Stand clear of popping corks.

articles.headline: Rivals Split, With Joe in the Middle
articles.snippet: In trying to cast doubt on Barack Obama, John McCain threw the kitchen sink at him -- along with the plumber.
articles.abstract: In trying to cast doubt on Barack Obama, John McCain threw the kitchen sink at him -- along with the plumber.
articles.lead_paragraph: Barack Obama looked like a prosecutor delivering a polished summation in a long civil case, Joe the Plumber v. George W. Bush.

articles.headline: UBS Given an Infusion of Capital
articles.snippet: The Swiss government said it would take a 9 percent stake in UBS and provide it with $5.36 billion in capital.
articles.abstract: The Swiss government said it would take a 9 percent stake in UBS and provide it with $5.36 billion in capital.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  Switzerland extended urgent help Thursday to its storied banking industry as the government acknowledged that even the world’s biggest wealth needed protection from the tumult gripping the global financial system.

articles.headline: Banks Are Likely to Hold Tight to Bailout Money
articles.snippet: As Citigroup and Merrill Lynch reported multibillion-dollar losses, some wondered what the nation’s lenders would do with the Treasury Department’s capital infusion.
articles.abstract: As Citigroup and Merrill Lynch reported multibillion-dollar losses, some wondered what the nation’s lenders would do with the Treasury Department’s capital infusion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as the government moves to plug holes in the nation’s banks, new gaps keep appearing.
articles.byline: By Louise Story and Eric Dash
